results.justification: The document states: "This study uses a case study design to explore the dialogic behaviors of preservice teachers and AI-powered student agents in interaction."
Sections 3.1-3.4 provide a detailed description of the simulation environment, participants, procedure, data collection, coding, and analysis.
The document does not mention the public availability of the raw or processed datasets.
While the document mentions data sources (e.g., recordings from open-access videos), it doesn't explicitly state why the datasets themselves aren't shared.
Table 1 provides a coding framework with examples, acting as a codebook. The document also describes the tagging process for the classroom recordings.
Section 3.2 and 3.3 detail the recruitment process, simulation setup, data recording, and transcript creation.
The document mentions using Python and R for analysis but does not provide a link to an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code is not shared.
The document does not mention the availability of code used for data preparation.
The document describes the use of a Generalized Sequence Pattern (GSP) algorithm and Markov Chain transition matrix for analysis.
The document reports support and confidence values for the identified patterns, providing a measure of reliability.
The document provides subjective context and interpretation of the results, comparing patterns between the simulated and in situ classrooms.
The data coding process is described, and the coding framework (Table 1) is shared.
Results are presented in text, tables (2, 3, 4), and figures (3, 4, 5), with clear descriptions and comparisons.
The discussion section acknowledges limitations, such as the text-based format of the simulation and potential issues with social presence.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
